titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Guide to Israel Amter Winona Piano Score TAM.232
titlestmt.author: Peter Meyer Filardo

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from Amter Winona template.doc

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-01-21 15:50:21 -0500.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.abstract: Israel Amter (1881-1954) was an official in the Communist Party, USA who had studied music at the Leipzig Conservatory, where in 1912 he composed a never-performed opera, Winona, which concerns the love between a U.S. army officer and a Native American woman, Winona.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials are open without restrictions, however, patrons must use photocopy.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Donald Amter in 2003. The accession number associated with this gift is 2003.018.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Israel Amter, founding member of the Communist Party, USA and a leading functionary into the 1940s, was born on March 26, 1881, in Denver to Jewish immigrant parents. He joined the Socialist Party in 1901, and in 1903 moved to Germany where he remained until 1914, editing the German Export Review, participating in the Social Democratic Party, and studying music at the Leipzig Conservatory, where he composed his never-performed opera Winona (1912), which concerns the love between a U.S. army officer and a Native American woman, Winona.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:

70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Contains the piano score for the opera Winona (150 pages), and a photocopy of the libretto (25 pages).

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by Israel Amter was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.
